Result.Title: The Effects of Poverty on Children

Result.Abstract: This paper uses data from a randomized housing-mobility experiment to study the effects of relocating families from high- to low-poverty neighborhoods on juvenile crime. Outcome measures come from juvenile arrest records taken from government administrative data. Our findings seem to suggest that providing families with the opportunity to move to lower-poverty neighborhoods reduces violent criminal behavior by teens. © 2001
Result.Title: Urban Poverty And Juvenile Crime: Evidence From A Randomized Housing-Mobility Experiment

Result.Abstract: Using 6 longitudinal data sets, the authors estimate links between three key elements of school readiness—school-entry academic, attention, and socioemotional skills—and later school reading and math achievement. Result.Title: School Readiness and Later Achievement

Result.Title: Using Sample Survey Weights in Multiple Regression Analyses of Stratified Samples

Result.Title: Correlations Between Neighboring Children In Their Subsequent Educational Attainment

Result.Abstract: This article examines the extent to which adolescents' expectations about their future in terms of health and education affect their risk-taking behavior. With data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health, we test the theory that a "nothing to lose" attitude about the future predicts greater involvement in risky behaviors involving early sexual intercourse, selling drugs, and weapon use.

Result.Title: The Endogeneity Problem in Developmental Studies

Result.Abstract:
Longitudinal data from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics and the German Socio-Economic Panel show that in the Federal Republic
 of Germany, women experience even sharper drops in economic status immediately after a marital split than in the United States,
 while German and American men fare about the same. German social policy does little to reduce the disparities.
Result.Title: Wife or frau, women do worse: A comparison of men and women in the United States and Germany after marital dissolution

Result.Title: Access to Social Capital

Result.Abstract: According to human capital theory, women's work participation decisions will strongly affect their wages and wage growth. We test human capital predictions about how labor force withdrawals, both past and prospective, part-time work experience, and working in "male" rather than in "female" jobs affect wages and wage growth for white women. Result.Title: A Longitudinal Analysis of White Women's Wages

Result.Title: Child Well-Being in an Era of Welfare Reform: The Sensitivity of Transitions in Development to Policy Change

Result.Title: Impacts on Children of a Policy to Promote Employment and Reduce Poverty for Low-Income Parents: New Hope After 5 Years

Result.Title: Time Limits and Welfare Reform: New Estimates of the Number and Characteristics of Affected Families

Journal.FullName: Journal of Policy Analysis and Management

Result.Abstract: Studies using nonexperimental data have generated little consensus on whether parental income promotes children's achievement. We revisit this issue by using random-assignment-induced variation in family income in four welfare and anti-poverty programs to identify income effects. Our results suggest that family income has a policy-relevant positive impact on the school achievement of preschool but not older children.
Result.Title: Does Money Really Matter? Estimating Impacts of Family Income on Children's Achievement with Data from Random-Assignment Experiments

Result.Title: Effects of Participation in the WIC Program on Birthweight: Evidence From the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth

Result.Title: Welfare Reform and Child Well-Being

Result.Title: Extent and consequences of welfare dependence among America's children

Result.Abstract: Over the past 30 years, welfare and other public programs for poor families have focused increasingly on promoting parents' self-sufficiency by requiring and supporting employment. This report summarizes the results of recent research
Result.Title: Effects of Welfare and Employment Policies on Young Children: New Findings on Policy Experiments Conducted in the Early 1990s
